summary: This document is an email chain from September 27, 2019, discussing a submission titled 'Labyrinth of Deception --Jeff Epstein' sent to the U.S. Attorney's Office. The core email from Patrick Disanto describes two film scripts containing public service announcements (PSAs) about victims of sexual predators, linking them to figures like Jeffrey Epstein, Harvey Weinstein, and others. It alleges a cover-up, intimidation of filmmakers, and the involvement of officials in 'sponsorship' of victims.

persons.name: Patrick Disanto
persons.context: Author of the initial email describing film scripts with PSAs about victims of predators like Epstein; claims to have been harassed and assaulted, and had his children removed due to his work.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central subject of the email; described as a predator directly connected to a young female victim mentioned in the film scripts.

persons.name: Harvey Weinstein
persons.context: Mentioned as a predator whose desk held scripts containing PSAs about an Epstein victim.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Identified as the U.S. Attorney covering the Epstein case; the email author asks for advice on presenting information to him.

persons.name: Martin Jacobsen
persons.context: Subject of the first film 'JAKE'; a soccer coach at Martin Luther King HS.

persons.name: Matt MacKlee
persons.context: Character portrayed by Patrick Disanto in the film '35 cents'.

persons.name: M. Jim Jenkins
persons.context: Attorney representing Patrick Disanto, located in Pensacola, Florida.

persons.name: Sylvia Penner
persons.context: Attorney associated with the law firm Fleeson, Gooing, Coulson & Kitch, LLC.

persons.name: Klein
persons.context: Mentioned as a predator alongside Epstein, Weinstein, Cooper, and Mandlebaum.

persons.name: Cooper
persons.context: Mentioned as a predator alongside Epstein, Weinstein, Klein, and Mandlebaum.

persons.name: Mandlebaum
persons.context: Mentioned as a predator alongside Epstein, Weinstein, Klein, and Cooper.

connections.description: Disanto's email and film work focus on exposing predators including Epstein, suggesting a researcher/subject relationship.
Disanto mentions scripts sat on Weinstein's desk containing PSAs about an Epstein victim.
Jenkins is listed as representation for Patrick Disanto.
Linked contextually as named predators in the same narrative about victim 'sponsorship'.
Berman is the U.S. Attorney covering the Epstein case, creating a prosecutor-subject relationship.

events.title: Creation of film 'JAKE' with PSA
events.description: First film 'JAKE' about soccer coach Martin Jacobsen created, containing a PSA about a 13-year-old female victim of Epstein because they could not directly draw attention to her situation.

events.title: Email submission to U.S. Attorney's Office
events.description: Patrick Disanto sends an email to the U.S. Attorney's Office detailing film scripts about predator victims and alleging official involvement and intimidation.

events.title: Harassment and assault of Patrick Disanto
events.description: Patrick Disanto reports being harassed by officials, having his children removed from custody, and being assaulted, which shut down film production.

events.title: Confiscation of research materials
events.description: Individuals involved allegedly confiscated most of the research findings from a storage locker belonging to the email author.

keyFacts: The email describes two film scripts from 2009 that contained public service announcements (PSAs) about victims of sexual predators, including a 13-year-old female victim connected to Jeffrey Epstein.
It alleges that the young female victim was 'sponsored' by a Canadian official and an American official, which is described as disturbing.
Patrick Disanto, who worked on the films, claims he faced severe retaliation including harassment by officials, removal of his children from custody, assault, and confiscation of his research.
The email links multiple high-profile accused predators including Jeffrey Epstein, Harvey Weinstein, Klein, Cooper, and Mandlebaum in the context of victim 'sponsorship'.
The correspondence shows internal discussion at the U.S. Attorney's Office about forwarding the information to FBI agents on the Epstein case.
